learning_outcomes.description: Apply a critical understanding of the history and politics of Indigenous and settler relations up to the present day.
To identify and critically evaluate the assumptions that drive policy frameworks and strategies.
Apply the necessary tools and skills for critical analysis in reading, textual analysis and writing.

Demonstrate that the recognition of and respect for cultural and social diversity is not just a matter of identifying racial categories or cultural practices, but also identifying and reflecting on the values and knowledge systems that inform them.
Grasp and assess the range of arguments and perspectives articulated across the Australian political landscape in relation to issues impacting upon Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples.

assessments.task_description:
Rationale

Our best learning takes place when we reflect on how our existing knowledge is disrupted or extended, affirmed or unsettled and when we are open with ourselves and others about where our knowledge comes from, what it is based on and how we come to know. Becoming aware of ourselves as active agents rather than passive receptors is an important part of critical thinking. This assessment complements the in-class opportunities to reflect on course content and share ideas and insights with one another.

Task

Video #1 (4 minutes)

Video #2 (7 minutes)

For each video reflection you will be provided with stimulus questions (see the Video Reflections folder in the Assessments module on Blackboard Ultra).

  1. Consider the questions and reflect on yourself in response to them.
  2. Write a script to help you keep focussed and on time.
  3. Use Echo video on Blackboard Ultra to video yourself.
  4. Submit the video by 5pm on the Friday of the relevant week (3 and 13).
  5. The video should open with your name and the number of your video (“My name is… this is my first/second.. video reflection”).
  6. Record your video in a quiet place. Speak clearly and to camera. Ensure your microphone is not muffled. Stick to the time requirement.

More detailed information

Refer to the Video Reflections folder in the Assessments module on Blackboard Ultra.

Marks available

Video #1 - Pass/Fail (5 marks or 0 marks)

Video #2 - 15 marks

Submission

Submit via the appropriate Turnitin link in the Video Reflections folder in the Assessments module on Blackboard Ultra.

Use of generative AI and MT in this assessment - NOT PERMITTED

The aim of this assessment is to reflect on your own thinking and knowledge and to notice your own responses to the topics discussed in class. The purpose is to deepen your critical engagement with these topics by becoming aware of the things that influence your understanding and approach to them. The marking criteria for this assessment address your ability to reflect rather than the content of your reflection. We want to hear from you. Accordingly, this assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Assignments for this course will be submitted electronically via Blackboard Ultra and using Turnitin.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Rationale

Indigenous politics and policy do not occur in a vacuum but rather in a dynamic relationship with non-Indigenous ideas and ways of knowing. When enquiring into Indigenous politics and policy it is therefore important to understand how these things are framed by non-Indigenous ideas and knowledges. This assessment task teaches us to see this framing - and how it structures what we know, rather than simply operating within that framing and so replicating its outcomes. This task develops the skills you will need for the Issues Analysis assessment.

A short paper critique (SPC) is a highly focussed analysis of a text that addresses its structural framing rather than its content. Unlike other critical analyses short paper critiques do not address the argument made in a text, but identify the framing that allows that argument to be made. Because this task is not easy there will be plenty of opportunity to practice and the feedback you get for each paper will help you improve.

Task

Complete 5x Short Paper Critiques on the texts listed under Short Paper Critiques in the course Reading List. Submit via Turnitin by the relevant due dates. These papers will be marked and feedback provided to help you improve.

Format

  • at the top of the page note your full name and student number and identify the text using correct referencing (see POLSIS Essay Guide)
  • in paragraph 1 use the author's own words to identify the issue/topic and the core argument made about it (125 words).
  • in paragraph 2 use the author's own words to reveal the framing of this issue/topic (125 words).

Stick to the format. Write in full sentences (i.e., not in dot point form or abbreviated English). Check your work for spelling and grammatical errors. Cite and reference correctly according to either APA 7th or Chicago footnote (https://guides/library.uq.edu.au/referencing).

More detailed information

Refer to the Short Paper Critiques folder in the Assessments module on Blackboard Ultra.

Marks available

Each of the 5 Short Paper Critiques is worth 4% for a possible total of 20%.

Submission

Submit each of the critiques in Word format (not pdf) via the relevant Turnitin link in the Short Paper Critiques folder in the Assessments module on Blackboard Ultra.

Use of generative AI and MT in this assessment - Limited Use Permitted

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies to assist with the 5 formative critiques, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

You may ONLY use AI/MT in this assessment to translate source material into your preferred language (e.g., from English to another language) for the purposes of clarifying your understanding of a text. All other work is to be completed by you, unaided by AI or MT.

You must reference any use of AI/MT using the format outlined in the UQ Library Guide for acknowledging and referencing AI/MT use

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Assignments for this course will be submitted electronically via Blackboard Ultra and using Turnitin. Please submit in Word format (not pdf).
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Rationale

Indigenous politics and policy do not occur in a vacuum but rather in a dynamic relationship with non-Indigenous ideas and ways of knowing. When enquiring into Indigenous politics and policy it is therefore important to understand how these things are framed by non-Indigenous ideas and knowledges. This assessment task teaches us to see this framing - and how it structures what we know, rather than simply operating within that framing and so replicating its outcomes.

Task

Complete a short paper critique under exam conditions in tutorial 8 (Week 12). A brief but novel text will be provided in the tutorial. This Short Paper Critique will be handwritten and no technology is allowed. Submit your response along with the stimulus text to your tutor at the end of the tutorial. These papers will be marked against the criteria but no feedback will be provided.

Format

  • at the top of the page note your full name and student number and identify the text using correct referencing (see POLSIS Essay Guide)
  • in paragraph 1 use the author's own words to identify the issue/topic and the core argument made about it (125 words).
  • in paragraph 2 use the author's own words to reveal the framing of this issue/topic (125 words).

Stick to the format. Write in full sentences (i.e., not in dot point form or abbreviated English). Check your work for spelling and grammatical errors. Cite and reference correctly according to either APA 7th or Chicago footnote (https://guides/library.uq.edu.au/referencing).

More detailed information

Refer to the Short Paper Critiques folder in the Assessments module on Blackboard Ultra.

Marks available

There are 20 marks available. You must pass this hurdle to pass the course, this means achieving a grade of at least 10/20 (50%)

Submission

Submit your hurdle critique to your tutor along with the stimulus text at the end of tutorial #8 (Week 12).

Use of generative AI and MT in this assessment - NOT PERMITTED

Students will be required to demonstrate competence in this task independent of AI and MT tools. No Al or MT technology will be permitted during the hurdle assessment.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The Hurdle Short Paper Critique will be completed under exam conditions in tutorial #8 (week 12). You will be presented with a brief but novel text and required to complete a handwritten 250-word SPC on that text during the tutorial (50 minutes). No technology will be allowed. Submit your work with the stimulus text to your tutor at the end of the tutorial.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
Rationale

This assessment allows you to explore a particular issue or topic of interest to you and to apply the structural critique we have been learning to a range of different source materials. The format of the assessment is designed to enable you to write a clear and succinct analysis of an issue or topic as it is presented. This skill is useful for both research and practice (e.g., policy, journalism, legal argument...). It will support your critical engagement with Indigenous politics and policy in your chosen professional field.

Task

Write a 2,500-word analysis of an issue of Indigenous politics and policy.

  1. Pick an issue from the list provided (see the Issues Analysis folder in the Assessments module on Blackboard Ultra for details).
  2. Research the scholarly literature and/or policy statements and/or the news media on the issue (you should aim to gather at least 8 sources to enable you to make a focus selection).
  3. Select 2 of these sources to concentrate on. You can choose sources that appear to present similar or different approaches to the issue.
  4. Identify how the issue is presented in these sources and what kinds of actions (if any) are proposed. Look for specific phrases (and accompanying images if relevant) that reveal the framing of the issue in the sources you have selected.
  5. Consider how this framing of the issue expresses one or more of the ideas discussed in the course (use the weekly quotes and the self-referencing gaze/displacement diagram as a guide for your thinking).
  6. Determine which of these ideas best exemplifies the framing you see in the sources you have selected.
  7. Follow the format outlined in the Issues Analysis folder on Blackboard Ultra to complete your analysis.

More detailed information

Refer to the Issues Analysis folder in the Assessments module on Blackboard Ultra.

Marks available

This assessment is worth a total of 40 marks.

Submission

Submit your Issues Analysis in Word format (not pdf) via the Turnitin link in the Issues Analysis folder on Blackboard Ultra.

Use of generative AI and MT in this assessment - Limited Use Permitted

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

You may ONLY use AI/MT in this assessment to translate source material into your preferred language (e.g., from English to another language) for the purposes of clarifying your understanding of a text. All other work is to be completed by you, unaided by AI or MT.

You must reference any use of AI/MT using the format outlined in the UQ Library Guide for acknowledging and referencing AI/MT use

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

Students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Assignments for this course will be submitted electronically via Blackboard Ultra and using Turnitin. Please submit in Word format (not pdf).
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 1: Introduction and Orientation

This week we will be settling into the course and unsettling some of the ideas we might bring with us to the study of Indigenous politics and policy. Please ensure you have viewed the pre-recorded video as this will help by providing some context and direction for this week.
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 1: Introduction and Orientation This week we will be settling into the course and unsettling some of the ideas we might bring with us to the study of Indigenous politics and policy. Please ensure you have viewed the pre-recorded video as this will help by providing some context and direction for this week.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 2: Worldviews

This week we will discuss worldviews and knowledge as originating in different approaches to being, and what this means when different ways of being, knowing and doing meet. This will help us begin to understand Indigenous politics and policy in the context of an ongoing relationship between different peoples. Please view the short pre-recording to help you engage with the content for this week.
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 2: Worldviews This week we will discuss worldviews and knowledge as originating in different approaches to being, and what this means when different ways of being, knowing and doing meet. This will help us begin to understand Indigenous politics and policy in the context of an ongoing relationship between different peoples. Please view the short pre-recording to help you engage with the content for this week.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 3: Ideas #1: Race, Racism and Racialism

This week we will look at the history of our relationship through the story of an Aboriginal family from south east Queensland.
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 3: Ideas #1: Race, Racism and Racialism This week we will look at the history of our relationship through the story of an Aboriginal family from south east Queensland.

learning_activities.topic:
Tutorial 1

Engage in dialogue around the stimulus question from the lecture in Week 2.
learning_activities.topic_description: Tutorial 1 Engage in dialogue around the stimulus question from the lecture in Week 2.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 4: Ideas #2: Liberalism and Colonialism

This week we will look at some of the foundational political ideas Europeans brought to this continent, how they are related and how they continue to shape this place (and us) today.
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 4: Ideas #2: Liberalism and Colonialism This week we will look at some of the foundational political ideas Europeans brought to this continent, how they are related and how they continue to shape this place (and us) today.

learning_activities.topic:
Tutorial 2

Engage in dialogue around the stimulus question from the lecture in Week 3.
learning_activities.topic_description: Tutorial 2 Engage in dialogue around the stimulus question from the lecture in Week 3.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 5: Ideas #3: Equality

This week we will think about the idea of equality, and what is meant by this. We will look at Aboriginal activism through the documentary Blood Brothers: Freedom Ride (2013).
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 5: Ideas #3: Equality This week we will think about the idea of equality, and what is meant by this. We will look at Aboriginal activism through the documentary Blood Brothers: Freedom Ride (2013).

learning_activities.topic:
Tutorial 3

Engage in dialogue around the stimulus question from the lecture in Week 4.
learning_activities.topic_description: Tutorial 3 Engage in dialogue around the stimulus question from the lecture in Week 4.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 6: Ideas #4: Self-determination

This week we will address another idea prevalent in Indigenous politics and policy, that of self-determination, and how this idea is understood and used and to what ends.
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 6: Ideas #4: Self-determination This week we will address another idea prevalent in Indigenous politics and policy, that of self-determination, and how this idea is understood and used and to what ends.

learning_activities.topic:
Tutorial 4

Engage in dialogue around the stimulus question from the lecture in Week 5.
learning_activities.topic_description: Tutorial 4 Engage in dialogue around the stimulus question from the lecture in Week 5.

learning_activities.topic:
MID-SEMESTER BREAK

Please do schedule a rest this week! Enjoy time with friends or family, and do things that refresh and revive you.
learning_activities.topic_description: MID-SEMESTER BREAK Please do schedule a rest this week! Enjoy time with friends or family, and do things that refresh and revive you.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 7: Issues & Responses #1: Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody (RCIADIC) 1991

This week we move from looking at ideas to looking at how these ideas are manifest in Indigenous politics and policy in Australia. This week we address the 1991 Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody which was perhaps Australia's most successful royal commission in terms of identifying the causes of high incarceration and deaths in custody among Indigenous Australians.
learning_activities.topic_title: Week 7: Issues & Responses #1: Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody (RCIADIC) 1991
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 7: Issues & Responses #1: Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody (RCIADIC) 1991 This week we move from looking at ideas to looking at how these ideas are manifest in Indigenous politics and policy in Australia. This week we address the 1991 Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody which was perhaps Australia's most successful royal commission in terms of identifying the causes of high incarceration and deaths in custody among Indigenous Australians.

learning_activities.topic:
Tutorial 5

Engage in dialogue around the stimulus question from the lecture in Week 6.
learning_activities.topic_description: Tutorial 5 Engage in dialogue around the stimulus question from the lecture in Week 6.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 8: Explanations for Policy Failure

This week we ask how policy 'fails'. What do we mean by policy failure? How is this determined? We will look at the response when the anticipated outcome of policy is not achieved, and the reasons given for this.
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 8: Explanations for Policy Failure This week we ask how policy 'fails'. What do we mean by policy failure? How is this determined? We will look at the response when the anticipated outcome of policy is not achieved, and the reasons given for this.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 9: Issues & Responses #2: Northern Territory Emergency Responses (NTER) and Closing the Gap (CTG) 2007

In our second week looking at how ideas manifest in Indigenous politics and policy we turn our attention to the 2007 Northern Territory Emergency Response ('The Intervention') and the major strategic policy framework that came out of it, Closing the Gap.
learning_activities.topic_title: Week 9: Issues & Responses #2: Northern Territory Emergency Responses (NTER) and Closing the Gap (CTG) 2007
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 9: Issues & Responses #2: Northern Territory Emergency Responses (NTER) and Closing the Gap (CTG) 2007 In our second week looking at how ideas manifest in Indigenous politics and policy we turn our attention to the 2007 Northern Territory Emergency Response ('The Intervention') and the major strategic policy framework that came out of it, Closing the Gap.

learning_activities.topic:
Tutorial 6

Engage in dialogue around the stimulus question from the lecture in Week 8.
learning_activities.topic_description: Tutorial 6 Engage in dialogue around the stimulus question from the lecture in Week 8.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 10: NO LECTURE or TUTORIAL (Independent Study Week)

There is no lecture or tutorial this week. We strongly encourage you to use this time for your own independent study, particularly to begin thinking about your Issues Analysis assessment. Starting early and being clear about the task supports better outcomes. We will be available if you wish to make an appointment to discuss your assignment.
learning_activities.topic_title: Week 10: NO LECTURE or TUTORIAL (Independent Study Week)

We strongly encourage you to use this time for your own independent study, particularly to begin thinking about your Issues Analysis assessment. Starting early and being clear about the task supports better outcomes. We will be available if you wish to make an appointment to discuss your assignment.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 11: Issues & Responses #3: Native Title and The National Apology

Returning to how ideas manifest in Indigenous politics and policy, this week we take a look at the Native Title Act, 1993 (Cth), and the National Apology of 2008.
learning_activities.topic_title: Week 11: Issues & Responses #3: Native Title and The National Apology
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 11: Issues & Responses #3: Native Title and The National Apology Returning to how ideas manifest in Indigenous politics and policy, this week we take a look at the Native Title Act , 1993 (Cth), and the National Apology of 2008.

learning_activities.topic:
Tutorial 7

Engage in dialogue around the stimulus question from the lecture in Week 9.
learning_activities.topic_description: Tutorial 7 Engage in dialogue around the stimulus question from the lecture in Week 9.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 12: Issues & Responses #4: Truth, Treaty and Constitutional Recognition

One of the ideas and responses considered a 'solution' in Indigenous politics and policy is some form of official recognition of Indigenous peoples. This week we apply our critical thinking to the issues of truth-telling, treaty making and constitutional recognition.
learning_activities.topic_title: Week 12: Issues & Responses #4: Truth, Treaty and Constitutional Recognition
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 12: Issues & Responses #4: Truth, Treaty and Constitutional Recognition One of the ideas and responses considered a 'solution' in Indigenous politics and policy is some form of official recognition of Indigenous peoples. This week we apply our critical thinking to the issues of truth-telling, treaty making and constitutional recognition.

learning_activities.topic:
Tutorial 8 - HURDLE ASSESSMENT

In this week's tutorial we will complete the hurdle assessment task for this course. Please refer to section 6 (Assessment) of this Course Profile and to the Assessment Module on Blackboard for more information.
learning_activities.topic_description: Tutorial 8 - HURDLE ASSESSMENT In this week's tutorial we will complete the hurdle assessment task for this course. Please refer to section 6 (Assessment) of this Course Profile and to the Assessment Module on Blackboard for more information.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 13: Policy Object(ive)s and Political Relations

In our final week together we will have some fun as we reflect on Indigenous politics and policy and our learning in the course. We will watch a short 'mockumentary' and consider the significance of sausages to Australian political relations...

We will watch a short 'mockumentary' and consider the significance of sausages to Australian political relations...
